acts/act-1/act-1.html.title: ACT 1
acts/act-1/act-1.html.description: Our first ACT took place between October 6th and November

acts/acts.html.title: ACTs
acts/acts.html.description:
ACTs or Applied Creative Tasks are a series of tasks that we have to complete over the course of our Leaving Cert in this subject. There is a total of 3 ACTs, all having there own goal to complete: ACT 1: Ensemble Driven Piece of Theatre
ACT 2: Short Film
ACT 3: Theatre Piece or Short Film
The ACTs are group projects in which we must work together to produce a performance piece and record it. The Theatre Pieces must be performed to an audience and recorded. Likewise the Short Films are shown to an audience.

calendar/october-2025/etherville.html.title: Etherville
calendar/october-2025/etherville.html.description:
Synopsis
Our Work
Reflection Etherville by Eamonn Colfer is a short drama that we have studied. It details the story of the main character Elliot Dunne, a car accident victim who's quite severely disabled, barely able to do much with his legs and being confined to a wheelchair. He lives in an assisted living community for disabled people. A nurse and friend of his, Gail !Surname visits him to check up and make sure he's following his recovery plan.The titular place, Etherville, is a digital place in the virtual world, it's an open source project meaning that anyone can add to it and design things for it, allowing it to flourish and for individuals to escape from the harsh reality that many live in. One of these people that use it to escape from their own harsh reality is Elliot, allowing him to escape his disabilities and live freely in a world where he can walk around in once more. In the first scene where we see him using the headset, we see him and Sophie !Surname dancing gracefully to Tchaikovsky's Waltz of The Flowers. After they finish dancing ****We did a number of things based on the play including:
A Tableux Vivant[1], A 1 Minute Performance
We were put into groups of three on the 26th of September, my group consisted of: Myself Alex O'Brien Oliver Fagan
Alex had really wanted to be the director for the group but because there was no two male characters in a scene she couldn't, so Oliver volunteered himself, I had no particular interest in being the director anyways so that's what we went with. Alex and I were both actors for our work and Oliver was the director. On the 2nd of October we performed our pieces, starting with the Tableaux and then the 1 Minute Performance.
The Tableux Vivant[1-1] that we chose to do was one of the still shots from the opening scenes, specifically the one where Gail is looking for Elliot's emergency alert button and Elliot is just looking defeatedThe scene that we elected to do for our one minute performance was the ending scene of the drama, where Elliot is walking using crutches and has gained a happier stance in stark contrast to the beginning of the play. For the performance we used a number of props to help bring the story to life, which were a set of crutches, a music box and some tables and a chair to build the set. When deciding the section of the play we wanted to do, we all flicked through the scripts we were given and individually chose a scene, we then took the three scenes we'd chosen and then decided which of them to do. Me and Oliver had chosen the same scene, so we ended up going with that one.I think it was pretty easy to work in a group, at the beginning some people were a little reserved but after the first class and we'd all gotten into it, we worked well together and had fun. It was also nice to work in a smaller group rather than a massive one because it meant that individual opinions were heard and not ignored. My role as Elliot, was comprised of a lot of use of non-verbal communication as Elliot doesn't have many lines in the play apart from his monologue with Sophie. Personally I enjoyed my role because a lot of the expression and acting had to be non-verbal. For the next creative task, I think I could work a bit on rehearsing some actions and things to do while idle, such as when Gail is talking, I also could do a bit with my way of talking as I mostly stuck to my usual tone rather than something different to really embrace his character. I think that we had a pretty good performance overall and I enjoyed working with my team on this.
Tableux Vivant↩︎↩︎

calendar/october-2025/the-shadow-of-a-gu.title: The Shadow of a Gunman (Initial Viewing)
calendar/october-2025/the-shadow-of-a-gu.description:
Synopsis
My Thoughts
The Shadow of a Gunman by Sean O'Casey is a drama set during the Irish War of Independence, we follow Donal Davoren, he's a poet but everyone that knows him seems to think he's an IRA "Gunman", but he is not. He stays with Séamus Shields in a room in tenement housing, in the same building as several other characters that appear within the play. One of said characters, Mr Maguire, leaves a bag in the room, at the start of the play, like a Chekov's Gun[1] I suppose, but instead of a gun that has to be fired by the third act, it's a bag that has to be opened by the end. When Donal sees that everyone actually thinks he's a "Gunman" he plays into it, enjoying the attention and the air of mystery that it lends him, he calls himself "The Shadow of a Gunman" in a serious voice when he's alone in a scene. Another character, Minnie Powell, is the love interest of Donal, and falls in love with Donal, partially over him being a "Gunman" despite him not being one. Eventually this act of being a "Gunman" comes back to bite him for two reasons, a tenant from a neighbouring tenement, James Gallogher, comes to him with Julia Henderson asking for the IRA's help, and he gives Donal a letter. Another tenant of the tenement is Tommy Owens, a character that had showed up praising Donal and his involvement with the IRA. He sings out the window about the IRA and the "RA" which probably had some weight in the "Black and Tans" conducting a search of the tenement housing. And this is where our little Chekov's Bag comes to fruition, Donal and Séamus, check around the room to see if there's anything incriminating, the pair check the bag and realise it's full of bombs, Minnie takes them and hides them in her room because they won't search her room. Donal also remembers the letter which he frantically searches so he can burn it and get rid of it. Eventually the "Black and Tans" arrive and search the place, making a mess. After searching the building they arrest Minnie and take her away, but their wagon is ambushed by the IRA and she's shot.Personally I really enjoyed the drama, it's very entertaining and surprisingly tense, a lot of the humour still lands despite it being written a century ago. I really liked the use of lighting with the spotlights which were used sparingly, but when they were used they were very impactful, as well as with the Sun and Moon as physical objects that could be seen on the stage, it really helped with the immersion. The set design overall was fantastic, it looked lived in and real, rather than some artificial location, which is only made possible because of the singular location that is used throughout the drama. I also loved the way the wall split to show the stairway when the characters were looking out into it, that was very clever. The accents and facial expressions were very on point, they were extremely well done and put together. We only saw a recorded version of the show but I wouldn't be opposed to seeing a live performance.
Terminology > Chekov's Gun↩︎

headers.heading: The Shadow of a Gunman by Sean O'Casey

calendar/september-2025/creative-groups..title: Creative Groups
calendar/september-2025/creative-groups..description: I think the most crucial part of what makes a creative group work well together, is the desire & passion for the work. If no one is interested and passionate about working together and making a project come to life, they won’t be able to work well together. In addition to this I think it’s important for the members of the group to be of similar age/generation as this tends to have members being of the same culture and being able to connect easier. I also think in order for a creative project to be brought to life, the members need to have similar weight in the decision of what the work/project they’ll be doing will be.

headers.heading: What makes a creative group work well together?

calendar/september-2025/improvisation-on.title: Improvisation on the 8th
calendar/september-2025/improvisation-on.description: Improvisation is engaging in an activity that is not preplanned or prepared. There is spontaneity and freedom in the approach, allowing the activity to develop naturally without constraints.I was able to be creative in my approach to my work in class, particularly in the bit of adding sentences of the internal monologue to our Still Scenes from the previous class.I learned that I know a lot more that I previously realised and that I am not as bad as I thought I was with coming up with dialogue.I can try to retain everything I’ve learned and pay closer attention to the show that we’ll be attending on Into the Woods P1, next week.

headers.heading: What opportunity did I have to be creative with my class today?
What did I learn about myself?
Can I change anything for the next class?

calendar/september-2025/into-the-woods-p.title: Into the Woods P1
calendar/september-2025/into-the-woods-p.description: On Monday the 15th of September 2025, we saw a dress rehearsal of the Musical Into the Woods. The reflection for this show can be found in the Into the Woods P2 file, or below if the embedding feature works.Into The Woods by James Lopine, in my opinion is a fantastic show and needs to be watched/attended. The production that we attended in Gorey Little Theatre is no exception to that, the amazing team of set designers, actors, costume designers, musicians and make-up artists did a brilliant job at bringing this show to life. And it could even be seen by a blind man, that an incredible amount of love, care, time and effort went into this production.Now we only saw the dress rehearsal of act 1 on the night but it was brilliant nonetheless. During the show the team made excellent use of all sorts of techniques: The use of lighting was well done, they were still testing it while we were watching it because it was the dress rehearsal but they definitely got it spot on. Most might not have caught it but there were a couple of little soliloquies sprinkled in throughout the show. The costume design was spectacular especially for the witch, her entire face and identity was obscured till the very last moment at the end when she transforms. The set design I think was one of the best I've ever seen if not the best I've seen, creating an amazing atmosphere. The singing was brilliant as well, I have quite a fondness for musicals so that aspect of the show really spoke to me, so much that the main song with the whole cast saying "Into The Woods, dun dun Into the Woods..." has been stuck in my mind ever since. I would absolutely love to see more musicals in the future as per my aforementioned fondness of them, but I understand if this isn't possible.

calendar/september-2025/into-the-woods-p.title: Into the Woods P2

calendar/september-2025/stage-plan-&-mon.title: Stage Plan & Monologue
calendar/september-2025/stage-plan-&-mon.description: (The aforementioned stage plan can be found in my Physical Portfolio, or alternatively here)C1: “This idiot has no idea what’s coming to him. I’m gonna blow his stupid little head off. Why couldn’t he have just stuck to the plan, everything would’ve been fine, but noooo, he had to get greedy, well he knew what the boss said." C1, in a kind of high and mighty mock voice: 'He said 'Go in and bring back the boy and the girl unharmed' and yet here lies the boy, dead on the floor. And it’s not like we can just get rid of him now. Oh what am I do to now."

home.html.title: Home
home.html.description:
Hello, welcome to the digital part of my Drama, Film & Theatre PortfolioWithin this site is my journey through this subject, in website form because I didn't like how inexpressive Google Docs or Microsoft Word was, I wanted to show my passion and my love of creativity so I created this website, allowing me much more freedom.To explore the portfolio there is two options, you either Click from link to link to traverse through the pages, starting on the Calendar page. OR
Use the file explorer feature on the left hand side of the screen to see each individual page, though I'd recommend using the #Month pages to see the entries in an organised form.
Throughout my portfolio, you'll find many terms highlighted in Red, these terms will have a footnote that can be clicked on which will bring you to the Terminology where you can find their definition.P.S. Please ignore the sync and index files, I don't know why they're there, I deleted them but they won't go away.

readme.html.title: README
readme.html.description: Hello welcome to the Drama, Film and Theatre portfolio of Name. I'm studying the subject in GCS from 2025 to 2027.

terminology.html.title: Terminology
terminology.html.description:
This page will contain a number of terms that some people may not know that appear throughout my digital portfolio.
Chekov's Gun is a plot device that once introduced, must have significance later on in the story. It comes from the Russian playwright Anton Chekov who gave the advice about including such plot devices, with the famous line, "One must never place a loaded rifle on the stage if it isn't going to go off." This is where the "Gun" part of Chekov's Gun comes from. A Tableaux Vivant, also known as a still scene or a living picture, is a method of telling a story with no moving parts, all of the actors are perfectly stationary.

info_showOrphanNodes.description: Show nodes that are not connected to any other nodes.

info_showAttachments.description: Show attachments like images and PDFs as nodes in the graph.

info_allowGlobalGraph.description: Allow the user to view the global graph of all nodes.

info_allowExpand.description: Allow the user to pop-out the graph view to take up the whole screen

info_attractionForce.description: How much should linked nodes attract each other? This will make the graph appear more clustered.

info_linkLength.description: How long should the links between nodes be? The shorter the links the more connected nodes will cluster together.

info_repulsionForce.description: How much should nodes repel each other? This will make disconnected parts more spread out.

info_centralForce.description: How much should nodes be attracted to the center? This will make the graph appear more dense and circular.

info_edgePruning.description: Edges with a length above this threshold will not be rendered, however they will still contribute to the simulation. This can help large tangled graphs look more organised. Hovering over a node will still display these links.

info_minNodeRadius.description: How small should the smallest nodes be? The smaller a node is the less it will attract other nodes.

info_maxNodeRadius.description: How large should the largest nodes be? Nodes are sized by how many links they have. The larger a node is the more it will attract other nodes. This can be used to create a good grouping around the most important nodes.

info_allowResizing.description: Whether or not to allow the sidebars to be resized

info_allowCollapsing.description: Whether or not to allow the sidebars to be collapsed

info_rightDefaultWidth.description: The default width of the right sidebar

info_leftDefaultWidth.description: The default width of the left sidebar

info_allowFoldingLists.description: Whether or not to allow lists to be folded

info_allowFoldingHeadings.description: Whether or not to allow headings to be folded

info_siteUrl.description: The url that this site will be hosted at

info_authorName.description: The name of the author of the site
